author: DAVID RICCIO
title: Gareth Widdop to play for the Dragons against Canterbury
text:
JUST 10 days ago, the colour of Gareth Widdop’s quad resembled the purple jersey he wore over four seasons with the Melbourne Storm.
Taken to hospital with internal bleeding of his quad following a weights session, there were genuine fears within the St George Illawarra camp that Widdop’s season could be over.
And with that, so too the premiership hopes of the proud Red V.

Such was the renewed confidence in his powerful left anchor, Widdop even resumed his routine of weekly goalkicking practice to complete the session.
The English international only needs to wake this morning without any further swelling to line up at five-eighth for the Dragons in their elimination final against Canterbury tonight at ANZ Stadium.
Such is the importance of Widdop’s anticipated inclusion, when news broke of his sharp training run yesterday, the TAB reacted by tightening the Dragons odds to win tonight from $4.10 to $3.85.

Despite this year’s ledger standing 1-1, after the Dragons beat the Bulldogs 31-6 in round six and then Canterbury returned serve with a 29-16 win in round 13, Des Hasler’s side remain short-priced favourites at $1.28.
And in a further boost for the Dragons’ do-or-die collision, hard-running backrower Joel Thompson (hamstring) also trained with enough intent yesterday to suggest he will force his way onto the Dragons interchange bench.
But the return of Widdop is why Saints fans will arrive at Homebush with their nostrils tickled by the sweet smell of September.
Widdop has been one of the Dragons best all season. To describe the comeback of Widdop as timely would be to underestimate the significance and influence the 26-year-old has had on the Dragons since making his club debut in round one, 2014.
In 23 appearances for Saints this season, Widdop has provided 20 try assists, scored more tries (nine) than any other player for the Dragons while also landing 78 per cent of his goal-kicks.
His combination with halves partner Benji Marshall — who returns to the finals arena tonight for the first time since 2011 — is the key to success for the Dragons tonight.
Marshall holds such a high regard for Widdop that he recently described their partnership as similar to the one he shared with Scott Prince when they combined to lift the NRL premiership trophy at the Wests Tigers in 2005.
Dragons coach Paul McGregor said that with his side’s position as “rank outsiders’ came the prospect of playing tonight without “any pressure.’’
“It’s (training) been really positive,’’ McGregor said.
“It’s a place where everyone wants to be at this time of year and for a group that’s come together last October and worked so hard over the last 10 months, it’s really important we go out and put our best foot forward against Canterbury.
“It’s a new competition starting and for us it’s about playing better than the Bulldogs, for one day of the year, which is this weekend.
“Regardless of what has happened previously with their club or our club during the year, it’s about us putting the best 80 minutes of football we possibly can.’’
